docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.title: Using annotations¶
docs.text:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, (1) consectetur adipiscing elit.

  1. :man_raising_hand: I'm an annotation! I can contain code, formatted text, images, ... basically anything that can be expressed in Markdown.

docs.title: Highlighting specific lines
docs.text:
Specific lines can be highlighted by passing the line numbers to the hl_lines argument placed right after the language shortcode. Note that line counts start at 1, regardless of the starting line number specified as part of linenums:

def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Footnotes
docs.text: Lorem ipsum[^1] dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.[^2]

docs.title: Highlighting changes
docs.text:
• [Critic]{ data-preview="" }
  • [Caret, Mark & Tilde]{ data-preview="" }

When [Critic] is enabled, [Critic Markup] can be used, which adds the ability to highlight suggested changes, as well as add inline comments to a document:

Text with suggested changes
Text can be deleted and replacement text added. This can also be
combined into onea single operation. Highlighting is also
possible and comments can be added inline.

Formatting can also be applied to blocks by putting the opening and closing tags on separate lines and adding new lines between the tags and the content.

docs.title: Image captions
docs.text:
Sadly, the Markdown syntax doesn't provide native support for image captions, but it's always possible to use the [Markdown in HTML] extension with literal figure and figcaption tags:

Image with caption
<figure markdown>
  ![Image title](https://dummyimage.com/600x400/){ width="300" }
  <figcaption>Image caption</figcaption>
</figure>
Image caption
